withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[0]: the act of moving an army, weapons etc away from the area where they were fighting
withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[1]: the removal or stopping of something such as support, an offer, or a service
withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[2]: the act of taking money from a bank account, or the amount you take out
Customers can use the machine to make withdrawals of up to £250 a day.
withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[3]: the act of no longer taking part in an activity or being a member of an organization
withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[4]: the period after someone has given up a drug that they were dependent on, and the unpleasant mental and physical effects that this causes
withdrawal.translation[0].definitions[5]: the act of saying that something you previously said was in fact untrue
withdrawal.translation[1].definitions[0]: the act of taking money from a bank account, or the amount you take out
There are penalties for the early withdrawal of savings.
withdrawal.translation[1].definitions[1]: the removal or stopping of something such as support, an offer, or a service
withdrawal.translation[1].definitions[2]: when a product is made no longer available, either for a period of time or permanently
The Environmental Health Services will be aware of a product withdrawal of the company’s bottled still water.
withdrawal.translation[1].definitions[3]: when someone no longer takes part in an activity or is no longer a member of an organization
Poor profits resulted in the company’s withdrawal from its computer games and entertainment business.
withdrawal.translation[1].definitions[4]: when you say that something you previously said was in fact untrue
The case ended with the complete withdrawal of allegations against the detainees held without trial.
